tn.ref: The plans of the heart belong to a person
tn.text: Here the word "heart" represents the person's mind and thoughts. AT: "A person makes plans in his mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: from Yahweh comes the answer from his tongue
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh speaks his answer to a person's plans, which is a metaphor meaning that Yahweh determines the outcome of that person's plans or 2) Yahweh enables a person to speak words about the plans that he has made. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the answer from his tongue
tn.text: This phrase is a metonym for the words that one speaks. AT: "the answer that he speaks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: All of a person's ways are pure in his own eyes
tn.text: The word "eyes" is a metonym for the way a person thinks about right and wrong. The writer speaks of what a person does as if that person were walking down a path. AT: "A person thinks that everything he does is pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Yahweh weighs the spirits
tn.text: Here the word "spirits" represents people's desires and motives. The writer speaks of Yahweh discerning and judging a person's desires and motives as if he were weighing that person's spirit. AT: "Yahweh judges the person's motives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: even the wicked for the day of trouble
tn.text: The verbal phrase may be supplied from the previous phrase. AT: "he has made even the wicked for the day of trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: everyone who has an arrogant heart
tn.text: Here the word "heart" represents the person. AT: "everyone who is arrogant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: they will not go unpunished
tn.text: The two negatives in this phrase strongly emphasize the positive. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will certainly punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: By covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness iniquity is atoned for
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh atones for iniquity by covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: people turn away from evil
tn.text: The writer speaks of people no longer doing evil things as if they were turning away from evil. AT: "people stop doing evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he makes
tn.text: "Yahweh makes"

tn.ref: a large income
tn.text: "earning a lot of money"

tn.ref: injustice
tn.text: "wrongdoing"

tn.ref: In his heart a person plans out his way
tn.text: Here the word "heart" represents the mind and thoughts. The writer speaks of a person's actions as if the person were walking on a path. AT: "A person plans in his mind what he will do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Yahweh directs his steps
tn.text: The writer speaks of Yahweh determining the outcome of a person's plans as if Yahweh were telling that person where to walk. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: An oracle is on the lips of a king
tn.text: Here the word "lips" is a metonym for what the king says. AT: "What a king says is an oracle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: An oracle
tn.text: a decision from God, a divine verdict

tn.ref: in judgment his mouth does not speak deceitfully
tn.text: The word "mouth" represents the king himself. AT: "when he pronounces judgment, he does not speak deceitfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: his mouth does not speak deceitfully
tn.text: This can be stated in positive terms. AT: "he speaks truthfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: Honest scales come from Yahweh
tn.text: Yahweh requires justice and fairness when doing business. Dishonest people used heavier or lighter weights in their scales in order to gain more when buying or selling. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: all the weights in the bag are his work
tn.text: Merchants carried their weights in bags. Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh has determined how much every weight must weigh or 2) Yahweh is concerned with every weight that a merchant uses.

tn.ref: that is something to be despised
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that is something that people despise" or "that is something that Yahweh despises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: for a throne is established by doing what is right
tn.text: Here the word "throne" represents the king's rule. This can be stated in active form. AT: "for the king establishes his reign by doing what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: lips that say what is right
tn.text: Here the word "lips" represents the person who speaks. AT: "a person who speaks the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: A king's wrath is a messenger of death
tn.text: The writer speaks of an angry king causing someone to die as if the king's wrath were a messenger that he sends out to kill someone. AT: "An angry king can put people to death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Verse 15 contrasts with verse 14.

tn.ref: In the light of a king's face is life
tn.text: The writer speaks of an expression of joy on the king's face as if his face emitted light. AT: "When the king is cheerful, people live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: his favor is like a cloud that brings a spring rain
tn.text: The writer compares the king showing favor towards someone with a cloud that brings rain to make crops grow. Both promise blessing to those who receive them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: How much better it is to get wisdom than gold
tn.text: This exclamation emphasizes that having wisdom is much better than having gold. AT: "It is much better to get wisdom than to get gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])

tn.ref: To get understanding should be chosen more than silver
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "A person should choose to get understanding more than to get silver" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The highway of upright people
tn.text: The writer speaks of the lifestyle of upright people as if it were a well-built road, free of obstacles. AT: "The righteous way that upright people live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: turns away from evil
tn.text: The writer speaks of avoiding or no longer doing evil things as if it were turning away from evil. AT: "keeps them from doing evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a haughty spirit
tn.text: Here the word "spirit" represents the person's attitude and temperament. AT: "an arrogant attitude" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: a downfall
tn.text: "ruin" or "failure"

tn.ref: spoil
tn.text: goods taken in battle

tn.ref: what they are taught
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "what someone has taught them" or "what they have learned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The one who is wise in heart is called discerning
tn.text: This person will have a reputation of being a discerning person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "People will call the one who is wise in heart discerning" or "The one who is wise in heart will have a reputation of being a discerning person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The one who is wise in heart
tn.text: Here the heart represents the mind and thoughts. AT: "The one who is wise" or "The one who is wise in his thinking" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: sweetness of speech
tn.text: The writer speaks of kind or pleasant speech as if it were something that tastes sweet. AT: "kind speech" or "pleasant speech" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Understanding is a fountain of life
tn.text: The writer speaks of "Understanding" as if it were a fountain that continuously flows with water and which sustains the life of those who drink from it. AT: "Understanding is like a fountain flowing with life-giving water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The heart of a wise person gives
tn.text: Here the word "heart" represents the mind and thoughts. AT: "The thoughts of a wise person gives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: gives insight to his mouth
tn.text: Here the word "mouth" is a metonym for speech. AT: "makes his speech wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to his lips
tn.text: Here the word "lips" is a metonym for speech. AT: "to what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Pleasant words are a honeycomb
tn.text: The writer speaks of pleasant words being able to bring delight to the hearers as if the words were a honeycomb dripping with fresh honey. AT: "Pleasant words are like a honeycomb" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: sweet to the soul
tn.text: Possible meanings for the word "soul" are 1) it represents a person's inward desires and pleasures. AT: "sweet enough to make a person happy" or 2) it can mean "throat" and is a metonym for a person's tongue and ability to taste. AT: "sweet to a person's taste" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: healing to the bones
tn.text: Here the word "bones" represent a person's body. AT: "healing to the body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: There is a way that seems right to a man
tn.text: The writer speaks of a person's conduct or behavior as if it were a road on which the person is traveling. AT: "A person thinks that the way he is living is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: but its end is the way to death
tn.text: The word "its" refers to "way" in the previous line. This "way" is the road that leads to death.

tn.ref: The laborer's appetite works for him
tn.text: The writer speaks of the appetite as if it were a person who works on behalf of the laborer. This means that the person who labors is motivated by his desire to eat. AT: "The laborer works to satisfy his appetite" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: his hunger urges him on
tn.text: The writer speaks of "hunger" as if it were a person who urges the laborer to continue working. AT: "he keeps on working because he is hungry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: A worthless person digs up mischief
tn.text: The writer speaks of a person trying to find ways to harm other people as if that person were digging in the ground to find something buried. AT: "A worthless person looks for mischief as if he were digging for something in the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: worthless
tn.text: "useless" or "wicked"

tn.ref: mischief
tn.text: "evil" or "trouble"

tn.ref: his speech is like a scorching fire
tn.text: The writer compares the way this person's words hurt others with the way that fire burns things. AT: "he hurts people with his words, like a fire scorches the things it touches" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: a gossip
tn.text: a person who gossips or spreads rumors

tn.ref: A man of violence lies to his neighbor
tn.text: It is implied that this man lies to his neighbor in order to get his neighbor to join him in violent actions. AT: "A man of violence entices his neighbor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: A man of violence
tn.text: "A violent man" or "A man who practices violence"

tn.ref: leads him down a path that is not good
tn.text: The writer speaks of a person's actions as if they were a road on which the person walks. AT: "gets him to do things that are not good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a path that is not good
tn.text: The writer uses an understatement to emphasize how bad this path is. AT: "a very bad path" or "a terrible path" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The one who winks the eye ... those who purse the lips
tn.text: Both of these are facial gestures which people might use to signal their plans to others. See how you translated "winks the eye" in [[:en:bible:notes:pro:10:10|10:10]].

tn.ref: will bring evil to pass
tn.text: "will do evil things"

tn.ref: Gray hair is a crown of glory
tn.text: The writer speaks of gray hair as if it were a crown. "Gray hair" is a metonym for old age. AT: "A person who has lived long enough to have gray hair is like one who wears a glorious crown on his head" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: it is gained
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "a person gains it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: one who rules his spirit
tn.text: The writer speaks of a person being able to control his own temper and emotions as if he ruled over his spirit like a king rules his people. AT: "one who controls his temper" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The lots are thrown into the lap
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "A person throws the lots into his lap" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the decision is from Yahweh
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh decides how the lots will land or 2) it is not the lots, but Yahweh who determines what will happen.
